commit_message:
Remove unused exceptions

There are four exceptions (TenantNetworksDisabled,
InvalidExtensionEnv, DvrHaRouterNotSupported,
MissingMinSubnetPoolPrefix) that are not used in Neutron, thus
unnecessary to have them in neutron/common/exceptions.py.

- TenantNetworksDisabled was added in [1] to Quantum, and was
  raised when the tenant network type was TYPE_NONE.
  It was used in the openvswitch and linuxbridge plugins in Quantum,
  but now there are no occurrences of usage.
  It is still used in the Neutron plugin of OpenContrail though,
  so complete removal may be inappropriate right now.

- InvalidExtensionEnv (previously InvalidExtenstionEnv, renamed in
  [2a]) was added in [2b] to Quantum. It was raised when the
  appropriate quota driver was not provided, thus the extension
  environment was invalid. The usage was removed in [2c].

- DvrHaRouterNotSupported was added in [3a], and was raised when the
  router was both DVR and HA (it was not supported by that time).
  The usage was removed in [3b].

- MissingMinSubnetPoolPrefix was added in [4]. I did not find any
  prior usage of this exception.

This patch removes the last three exceptions from exceptions.py,
and adds a note to the first about possible removal in the future.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/12362/

[2a]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23902/
[2b]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/10484/
[2c]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/23406/

[3a]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/143733/
[3b]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/196893/

[4]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/148698/

Change-Id: Id47044e1feea4aea0d375b922aea7bd6cc50ac08

commit_message:
Revert "Update Full stack config"

This reverts commit eaa9ab1d39406c460c5dc135d4dfdee1c08e8d90.

The mentioned commit causes the gate tempest jobs to run with the new
netvirt, even though some of them are defined to run with the old one.

Change-Id: I4ce69e60ef700739e9e5652cc1fa22cd5b7bc491

commit_message:
[opensuse] Enabling external loadbalancer feature

Adding config to enable OpenStack loadbalancer for Kubernetes
cluster as backend. By default we keep it disabled to avoid having
to inject the openstack credentials in the cluster always.

Change-Id: I02f690b220e933d492671f53724a604a167d5abb

commit_message:
doc: Start using oslo_config.sphinxext

Providing a sample configuration file is all well and good, but it's not
exactly designed for readability on the web. Make use of the 'sphinxext'
module built into oslo.config to do this.

Change-Id: I1a38dae44c644daae77066304a6fb5333105b92c

commit_message:
Revert "Only sync glance database on major versions"

The current major upgrade detection compares
the same variable against itself. It also takes
place after the new venv tag has been placed
and the local facts are refreshed so there's
no good way to figure out the origin version.

Additionally, the version_compare filter only
works with semver version strings which is
unnecessarily strict.

Additionally, there does not appear to be any
evidence in the glance documentation that
the db sync action requires services to be
shut down or any other orchestration, so the
previously implemented action of doing a db
sync on every playbook execution should be
just fine. If there is nothing for it to do (which
will be the case for a minor upgrade) then it
will do nothing. If there is something for it to
do (which will be the case for a major upgrade)
then it will do what needs to be done.

As such, there appears to be no point in
implementing this extra set of tasks and
conditionals.

This reverts commit 647c4e33f1fcba771f23f7aabf0dc061b22f79ab.

Change-Id: I3b5afae3b7abf58de0b71ec2e67df2c38b6da5e3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_glance refs/changes/98/482898/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db_sync" changed_when: false command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db_load_metadefs {{ glance_etc_dir }}/metadefs" changed_when: false
deleted_lines: - name: Check Glance DB version command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db version" become: yes become_user: "{{ glance_system_user_name }}" register: db_version changed_when: false # We only set to minor here if the version_compare filter passes, and we make # sure that can't be accessed unless there's actually a '.' in the version. # Passing in 'major' or 'testing' to version_compare causes a Jinja error. - name: Determine whether a major or minor release was installed set_fact: upgrade_type: |- {% set existing = glance_venv_tag %} {% set upgrade_type = 'major' %} {% if '.' in existing %} {% set existing_major = existing.split('.')[0] %} {% set venv_major = glance_venv_tag.split('.')[0] %} {% if existing_major != venv_major %} {% set upgrade_type = 'major' %} {% elif existing | version_compare(glance_venv_tag, '!=', strict=True) %} {% set upgrade_type = 'minor' %} {% endif %} {% endif %} {{ upgrade_type }} delegate_to: localhost command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db sync" changed_when: false when: upgrade_type == 'major' or db_version.stdout.startswith('Database is either not under migration control') command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db load_metadefs" changed_when: false when: upgrade_type == 'major' or db_version.stdout.startswith('Database is either not under migration control')

evidence in the glance documentation that
the db sync action requires services to be
shut down or any other orchestration, so the
previously implemented action of doing a db
sync on every playbook execution should be
just fine. If there is nothing for it to do (which
will be the case for a minor upgrade) then it
will do nothing. If there is something for it to
do (which will be the case for a major upgrade)
then it will do what needs to be done.

As such, there appears to be no point in
implementing this extra set of tasks and
conditionals.

This reverts commit 86ad493c7e12e821b2021bde20c5ae972b885ba1.

commit_message:
Revert "Only sync glance database on major versions"

The current major upgrade detection compares
the same variable against itself. It also takes
place after the new venv tag has been placed
and the local facts are refreshed so there's
no good way to figure out the origin version.

Additionally, the version_compare filter only
works with semver version strings which is
unnecessarily strict.

Additionally, there does not appear to be any
evidence in the glance documentation that
the db sync action requires services to be
shut down or any other orchestration, so the
previously implemented action of doing a db
sync on every playbook execution should be
just fine. If there is nothing for it to do (which
will be the case for a minor upgrade) then it
will do nothing. If there is something for it to
do (which will be the case for a major upgrade)
then it will do what needs to be done.

As such, there appears to be no point in
implementing this extra set of tasks and
conditionals.

This reverts the https://review.openstack.org/475470
part of commit 86ad493c7e12e821b2021bde20c5ae972b885ba1.

Change-Id: I49d973bb52eefd7c5b4884adc047471118158229
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_glance refs/changes/19/482919/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db_sync" command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db_load_metadefs {{ glance_etc_dir }}/metadefs"
deleted_lines: - name: Check Glance DB version command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db version" become: yes become_user: "{{ glance_system_user_name }}" register: db_version changed_when: false # We only set to minor here if the version_compare filter passes, and we make # sure that can't be accessed unless there's actually a '.' in the version. # Passing in 'major' or 'testing' to version_compare causes a Jinja error. - name: Determine whether a major or minor release was installed set_fact: upgrade_type: |- {% set existing = glance_venv_tag %} {% set upgrade_type = 'major' %} {% if '.' in existing %} {% set existing_major = existing.split('.')[0] %} {% set venv_major = glance_venv_tag.split('.')[0] %} {% if existing_major != venv_major %} {% set upgrade_type = 'major' %} {% elif existing | version_compare(glance_venv_tag, '!=', strict=True) %} {% set upgrade_type = 'minor' %} {% endif %} {% endif %} {{ upgrade_type }} delegate_to: localhost command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db sync" changed_when: false when: upgrade_type == 'major' or db_version.stdout.startswith('Database is either not under migration control') command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db load_metadefs" changed_when: false when: upgrade_type == 'major' or db_version.stdout.startswith('Database is either not under migration control')

commit_message:
Revert "Only sync glance database on major versions"

The current major upgrade detection compares
the same variable against itself. It also takes
place after the new venv tag has been placed
and the local facts are refreshed so there's
no good way to figure out the origin version.

Additionally, the version_compare filter only
works with semver version strings which is
unnecessarily strict.

Additionally, there does not appear to be any
evidence in the glance documentation that
the db sync action requires services to be
shut down or any other orchestration, so the
previously implemented action of doing a db
sync on every playbook execution should be
just fine. If there is nothing for it to do (which
will be the case for a minor upgrade) then it
will do nothing. If there is something for it to
do (which will be the case for a major upgrade)
then it will do what needs to be done.

As such, there appears to be no point in
implementing this extra set of tasks and
conditionals.

This reverts the https://review.openstack.org/475470
part of commit 8a5fb5df53a25d4c45e070f15ab036bc5617cb76.

Change-Id: Ia51c0ae1e2f81f662f5262c9f3d95027830a7d86

commit_message:
Add log events to each fullstack test

This patch adds log messages with the current test name to each
fullstack test. This will allow us to search for all logs happened
during a specific fullstack test.

Change-Id: I18024774acfaf2d08ff47358dcefab4b58f3d0bd

commit_message:
Get files from tarballs.o.o if possible (extjs, policy)

Few artifacts are already available on tarballs.openstack.org; use
them instead of sahara-files (the others should be migrated as well).

commit_message:
Cinder volume revert to snapshot

This patch implements the spec of reverting volume to
latest snapshot.
Related tempest and client patches:

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/463906/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/464903/

APIImpact
DocImpact
Partial-Implements: blueprint revert-volume-to-snapshot

Change-Id: Ib20d749c2118c350b5fa0361ed1811296d518a17

added_lines: def rollback_snapshot(self, context, volume, snapshot): """Rollback a volume from snapshot""" self.vg.revert(snapshot['name'])

commit_message:
Initial liveness probe script

This script checks DB and MQ connectivity. It can be used as
livenessProbe for Helm services.

Partial-Implements: blueprint healthchecks
Change-Id: I43ad3308d7708ee240c972b3ddb260c00fdad38c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm refs/changes/91/459591/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2017 The Openstack-Helm Authors. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. {{- define "helm-toolkit.health-check" }} #!/usr/bin/env python # This script does health checking of OpenStack services using 3 methods: # 1. Check DB connection using oslo.db. # 2. Check RabbitMQ connection using oslo.messaging. # 3. Check service status in the API call. import argparse import socket import sys from novaclient import client as nova_client from keystoneauth1 import loading from keystoneauth1 import session from oslo_config import cfg from oslo_db import options as db_options from oslo_db.sqlalchemy import session as db_session import oslo_messaging as messaging CONF = cfg.CONF def main(): parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="OpenStack services health " "checker.") parser.add_argument('--config-dir', metavar='DIR', help='Path to a config directory to pull `*.conf` ' 'files from. This file set is sorted, so as to ' 'provide a predictable parse order if individual ' 'options are over-ridden. The set is parsed ' 'after the file(s) specified via previous ' '--config-file, arguments hence over-ridden ' 'options in the directory take precedence.') parser.add_argument('--config-file', metavar='PATH', nargs='+', default=None, help='Path to a config file to use. Multiple config ' 'files can be specified, with values in later ' 'files taking precedence. Defaults to None.') parser.add_argument('--service', help='Name of OpenStack service.') parser.add_argument('--binary', help='Binary name of OpenStack service.') parser.add_argument('--database', action='store_true', default=False, help='Check database connection.') parser.add_argument('--queue', action='store_true', default=False, help='Check message queue connection.') parser.add_argument('--status', action='store_true', default=False, help='Check service status in the API.') args = parser.parse_args() conf = [] if args.config_dir: conf.append('--config-dir') conf.append(args.config_dir) if args.config_file: conf.append('--config-file') for f in args.config_file: conf.append(f) CONF(args=conf) db_options.set_defaults(CONF) if args.database: try: db_session.EngineFacade(CONF.database.connection, **dict(CONF.database)) except Exception as e: print e sys.exit(1) if args.queue: try: # FIXME(dulek): This hangs forever waiting for socket when failure # is due to networking issue. Needs some timeout. transport = messaging.get_transport(CONF) target = messaging.Target(topic='test') client = messaging.RPCClient(transport, target, timeout=1, retry=0).prepare() client.cast({}, 'test') except Exception as e: print e sys.exit(1) if args.status: loader = loading.get_plugin_loader('password') # FIXME(dulek): Load that from values.yaml. auth = loader.load_from_options(auth_url={{ tuple "identity" "admin" "admin" . | include "helm-toolkit.keystone_endpoint_uri_lookup" | quote }}, username='admin', password='password', project_name='admin', user_domain_name='default', project_domain_name='default') sess = session.Session(auth=auth) hostname = socket.gethostname() if args.service == 'nova': nova = nova_client.Client('2', session=sess) svcs = nova.services.list(binary=args.binary, host=hostname) if len(svcs) != 1: print 'Service is missing from the service list.' sys.exit(1) if svcs[0].state != 'up': print 'Service is down in service list.' sys.exit(1) if __name__ == '__main__': main() {{- end }}

commit_message:
Fix glance Upload large image haproxy timeout when using external

timeout options are added to glance-api but not for glance_api_external,
it should be added there also.

Change-Id: Idbd3dabbe24a5c71e70154dfde96c5c70eeefc10
Partial-bug: 1675637

commit_message:
Addition of Nuage as mechanism driver for ML2

Adding support for Nuage to be included as mechanism driver where
ML2 is the neutron core plugin. All the parameters required to
configure Nuage plugin are included in the puppet file.

commit_message:
Add node's properties/capabilities as dict support

This patch is adding support for treating the nodes
properties/capabilities as a dictionary instead string only.
Manipulating data in a dictionary (add, removing, replacing) is much
simpler than doing with a string.

For context, the Ironic API didn't support dict and other primitive
types before 98d4bfd3ec214f941d2f99bc8b5279bd0a9545ee, all values were
strings, that's why capabilities is what is at the moment.

Closes-Bug: #1421261
Change-Id: I5d28c176448c1b16a13569400ca76bed94d4d6a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/71/232571/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: :returns: An updated capability string or dictionary. is_dict = isinstance(current_capabilities, dict) current_capabilities = dict(x.split(':', 1) for x in current_capabilities.split(',')) else: current_capabilities = {} current_capabilities.update(new_capabilities) return (current_capabilities if is_dict else ','.join('%s:%s' % (key, value) for key, value in current_capabilities.items()))
deleted_lines: :returns: An updated capability string. cap_dict = {} cap_dict = dict(x.split(':', 1) for x in current_capabilities.split(',')) cap_dict.update(new_capabilities) return ','.join('%(key)s:%(value)s' % {'key': key, 'value': value} for key, value in cap_dict.items())

commit_message:
Add power_transition_started_at to the nodes table

This patch is introducing a new field called "power_transition_starter_at"
to the nodes database table. This field holds the UTC date and time
when the power state transition was started and will later be used for
calculating a timeout for power state transitions.

The database filters for retrieving the nodes based on date/time are also
part of this patch.

The ReST API part is not included as part of this patch. The API can be
done as a separate patch because it already has its own complexity
such as adding a new microversion, hiding the new field for older API
versions and so on.

Partial-Bug: #1588901
Change-Id: I9c976f4656461e45707c2f40f7b8683013ab610c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/42/327642/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add SIGHUP support for ironic-conductor service

This patch is adding support for SIGHUP for the ironic-conductor
service. When a SIGHUP is handled, the service will reload the mutable
configuration options [0] and setup the logs (in case a configuration
option such as "debug" from oslo.log has been changed).

[0] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.config/opts.html?highlight=mutable

Change-Id: Iabb1338e935dae3b76ece7f1d4bf562a2988451b
Partial-Bug: #1585595

commit_message:
CoreOS Image building: Ensure docker is started

In order to generate the coreos image the docker service should be up
and running. This patch is some logic to start the service as part of
the image building process.

Change-Id: I61d8429d5bc52a3a723b52e117a0bc0450ba5234
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-python-agent refs/changes/79/297079/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Start the docker service OS_VENDOR=$(lsb_release -i -s) if [[ "$OS_VENDOR" =~ (Ubuntu) || "$OS_VENDOR" =~ (Debian) || \ "$OS_VENDOR" =~ (LinuxMint) ]]; then sudo service docker restart elif [[ "$OS_VENDOR" =~ (Fedora) || "$OS_VENDOR" =~ (Red.*Hat) || \ "$OS_VENDOR" =~ (CentOS) ]]; then sudo systemctl restart docker fi

commit_message:
Only sync power state if node is ACTIVE (DO NOT MERGE)

This is a commit to trigger some discussion. Do we need to sync nodes in
any states? Now that we've introduced a couple of new states e.g ENROLL,
MANAGEABLE, INSPECTING, ZAPPING, CLEANING, etc... We should rethink about
this periodic task. The more I think about it seems that we should only
care about sync'ing the power state when the node is ACTIVE. That's
because that's the only place it really matters, when provisioning a
node ironic will do a REBOOT after configuring the enviroment and so on,
so the node being powered on or off is irrelevant.

Change-Id: I4cce6c19533458b618a23ee1adba37c6e371a12a

tear down a node at any phase of the deployment (DEPLOYING or DEPLOYWAIT).

If the deployment can not be stopped because the node is locked

commit_message:
Add support for deferring instance deletion to later

Nova expects to be able to delete an instance even when it's spawning
but prior to this patch only accepted interrupting a deployment when the
node was in DEPLOYWAIT state. This patch adds support to be able to
tear down a node at any phase of the deployment (DEPLOYING or DEPLOYWAIT).

If the deployment can not be stopped because the node is locked
(DEPLOYING) we will mark the node and unprovision it later. A periodic
task has been added and will query for such nodes and trigger the deletion
of the instance when possible.

Depends-On: I996b2970992995e27dc03af6109481e4a20df15a
Implements: blueprint lazy-delete-instances
Change-Id: I2f8754fa4d23e709b37cae746a91308f692ca555

commit_message:
Add a new docker centos Heat environment

We are unsetting the t-h-t default params for containers in
Ice7b57c25248634240a6dd6e14e6d411e7806326. As part of that
we need to specify a new environment file explicitly
for to continue using tripleoupstream containers.

Co-Authored-By: Ian Main <imain@redhat.com>

Depends-On: I125137ba45f608cf84ea0a7146edd744a549d23b
Change-Id: I30205228eb55f81728c5fb79c25a4f67c0972357

commit_message:
Don't confuse Heat with empty parameter_defaults

Apparently providing completely empty parameter_defaults in an
environment file can confuse Heat, and it seems like it doesn't try to
deploy any services on the overcloud in the multinode job. See the bug
for more details about the bug symptoms.

Change-Id: Ia9cb01b48087b78f66004263757590877219f743
Closes-Bug: #1703599

commit_message:
placement: claim resources in scheduler

Modifies the scheduler manager to attempt a claim of resources against
the hosts that were selected by the scheduler during
select_destinations(). The "claim of resources" is merely taking the
first allocation request from the allocation candidates list that
contains the host returned from select_destinations() and using that
allocation request in a call to the placement API's PUT
/allocations/{consumer_uuid} call.

Change-Id: I39db95a961814370019edd0f516a2bc5db1146e8
blueprint: placement-allocation-requests
blueprint: nova-pike-claims-in-schedulers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/32/476632/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def claim_resources(self, consumer_uuid, alloc_request): """Creates allocation records for the supplied instance UUID against the supplied resource providers. :param consumer_uuid: The instance's UUID. :param alloc_request: The JSON body of the request to make to the placement's PUT /allocations API :returns: True if the allocations were created, False otherwise. """ url = '/allocations/%s' % consumer_uuid r = self.put(url, alloc_request) if r.status_code != 204: LOG.warning( 'Unable to submit allocation for instance ' '%(uuid)s (%(code)i %(text)s)', {'uuid': consumer_uuid, 'code': r.status_code, 'text': r.text}) return r.status_code == 204 @safe_connect

commit_message:
Add health check to sensu-client container

This patch adds HEALTHCHECK directive to sensu client image according to spec [1].

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/465633
Implements: blueprint container-healthchecks

Change-Id: I4c5e2a7a610a8a120145d3cd624920600ea6b24e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/98/470298/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # install healthcheck script COPY healthcheck /openstack/healthcheck RUN chmod -R 755 /openstack HEALTHCHECK CMD /openstack/healthcheck

commit_message:
XtremIO: fix fetching FC targets from X2 array

Previous versions of XtremIO had the type as part of the target name, in
X2 this convention was changed and a driver updated is required to query
the type from the target object.

Closes-Bug: #1702458
Change-Id: Ie62d7bc84b8b0e54ff627a52763e93456ff45d65

commit_message:
Only sync glance database on major versions

Since Glance doesn't yet have rolling upgrades, nor is the tooling
idempotent, we avoid running the database operations during minor
upgrades to maintain uptime.

Major upgrades will still run the sync operations, and the database will
be synced if there is no existing database regardless of the type of
upgrade.

In order for a load balancer to know that a service should be drained,
we must set a flag within the role communicating the update.

Combined backport of:
https://review.openstack.org/475470
https://review.openstack.org/478214

Change-Id: I4a4d8f23f05a16d25878340ede019be7ccdb7196
(cherry picked from commit 647c4e33f1fcba771f23f7aabf0dc061b22f79ab)

added_lines: - name: Check Glance DB version command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db version" register: db_version changed_when: false # We only set to minor here if the version_compare filter passes, and we make # sure that can't be accessed unless there's actually a '.' in the version. # Passing in 'major' or 'testing' to version_compare causes a Jinja error. - name: Determine whether a major or minor release was installed set_fact: upgrade_type: |- {% set existing = glance_venv_tag %} {% set upgrade_type = 'major' %} {% if '.' in existing %} {% set existing_major = existing.split('.')[0] %} {% set venv_major = glance_venv_tag.split('.')[0] %} {% if existing_major != venv_major %} {% set upgrade_type = 'major' %} {% elif existing | version_compare(glance_venv_tag, '!=', strict=True) %} {% set upgrade_type = 'minor' %} {% endif %} {% endif %} {{ upgrade_type }} delegate_to: localhost - name: Perform a Glance DB sync command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db sync" changed_when: false become: yes become_user: "{{ glance_system_user_name }}" when: upgrade_type == 'major' or db_version.stdout.startswith('Database is either not under migration control') command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db load_metadefs" changed_when: false when: upgrade_type == 'major' or db_version.stdout.startswith('Database is either not under migration control')
deleted_lines: - name: Perform a Glance DB sync command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db_sync" command: "{{ glance_bin }}/glance-manage db_load_metadefs {{ glance_etc_dir }}/metadefs"

commit_message:
Only sync glance database on major versions

Since Glance doesn't yet have rolling upgrades, nor is the tooling
idempotent, we avoid running the database operations during minor
upgrades to maintain uptime.

Major upgrades will still run the sync operations, and the database will
be synced if there is no existing database regardless of the type of
upgrade.

In order for a load balancer to know that a service should be drained,
we must set a flag within the role communicating the update.

Combined backport of:
https://review.openstack.org/475470
https://review.openstack.org/478214

Change-Id: I4a4d8f23f05a16d25878340ede019be7ccdb7196
(cherry picked from commit 647c4e33f1fcba771f23f7aabf0dc061b22f79ab)

commit_message:
Add flag to include all images in image list

Recent Glance v2 hides images that are shared but not accepted. The
way to see them is to send member_status=all, which is a bit low-level
for a shade user to need to know.

Add a show_all to list_images that defaults to False so that behavior
doesn't change. Don't add it to search_images, because at the
search_images level the user has the ability to pass in whatever filters
they want.

Change-Id: Ida2ea943168f5be56a60a94576bdcc6c8e1a9d24
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/02/481702/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def list_images(self, filter_deleted=True, show_all=False): :param show_all: Show all images, including images that are shared but not accepted. (By default in glance v2 shared image that have not been accepted are not shown) show_all will override the value of filter_deleted to False. if show_all: filter_deleted = False params = {} if show_all: params['member_status'] = 'all' response = self._image_client.get(endpoint, params=params)

commit_message:
Correct major upgrade detection logic

The current major upgrade detection compares
the same variable against itself. It also takes
place after the new venv tag has been placed
and the local facts are refreshed so there's
no good way to figure out the origin version.

Additionally, the version_compare filter only
works with semver version strings which is
unnecessarily strict.

This comparison is simpler, only cares about
whether this is a major upgrade or not and
figures that out at the right time.

Change-Id: I7a6e68309de8c5a0a8fb35228adf61f5dbab0fec

commit_message:
Add OVN specific neutron-server container

This patch creates a specific OVN neutron-server container
which uses neutron-server as its base and adds OVN specific
packages similar to this commit [1] which adds ODL specific
neutron-server

[1] - I610b07a3c2bcf1c3288f76112a08b81c50e06913

Change-Id: Iee1d04d08609e4492a7a799b5ac9c0991898887d
Partially-implements: blueprint ovn-controller-neutron

commit_message:
Only sync glance database on major versions

Since Glance doesn't yet have rolling upgrades, nor is the tooling
idempotent, we avoid running the database operations during minor
upgrades to maintain uptime.

Major upgrades will still run the sync operations, and the database will
be synced if there is no existing database regardless of the type of
upgrade.

Change-Id: I4a4d8f23f05a16d25878340ede019be7ccdb7196

added_lines: - name: Determine whether a major or minor release was installed set_fact: upgrade_type: | {%- set existing_version = ansible_local.get('glance_venv_tag', None) %} {%- if existing_version is None %} {%- set upgrade_type = 'major' %} {%- else %} {%- set existing_major = existing_version.split('.')[0] %} {%- set installed_major = glance_venv_tag.split('.')[0] %} {%- if existing_major != installed_major %} {%- set upgrade_type = 'major' %} {%- elif existing_version | version_compare(glance_venv_tag, '!=', strict=True) %} {% set upgrade_type = 'major' %} {%- endif %} {%- endif %} {{ deployment_type }} when: inventory_hostname == glance_all[0]

commit_message:
move config-reference.html to /configuration/

Move the list of configuration reference guides so the path in the URL
is /configuration/

Change-Id: Ie4cb95b2b9e81b4d4c9316758f14af66068d6b60
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
link to list of api guides from main page

Rather than linking only to the API quick start guide, which has been
removed, link to the template page showing the list of API documentation
available.

Rename api-ref-guides.html to index.html so that visiting
docs.openstack.org/api/ gives a list of the API guides.

Change-Id: I97b64d65800206c47f7fabfcf291fb0a337494b8
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/78/482578/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
L3 app: use port/router keys in PACKET_IN handler

L3 app used packet's MAC address to find the relevant port IP. Since
MACs are not unique across projects or networks, we can resolve an
incorrect IP address. This uses router/port keys to find the relevant
resource.

Closes-Bug: #1697439
Change-Id: I2925db5c00fcad256159306fec455b8b3c4cf8bc

added_lines: def _handle_ttl_expired(self, msg): if self.ttl_invalid_handler_rate_limit(): LOG.warning("Get more than %(rate)s TTL invalid packets per " "second at table %(table)s", {'rate': self.conf.router_ttl_invalid_max_rate, 'table': const.L3_LOOKUP_TABLE}) return LOG.debug("Get an invalid TTL packet at table %s", const.L3_LOOKUP_TABLE) pkt = packet.Packet(msg.data) e_pkt = pkt.get_protocol(ethernet.ethernet) router_key = msg.match.get('reg5') lrouter = self.db_store.get_one( l3.LogicalRouter(unique_key=router_key), index=l3.LogicalRouter.get_index('unique_key'), ) router_port_ip = None for port in lrouter.ports: if port.mac == e_pkt.dst: router_port_ip = port.network.ip break if router_port_ip: icmp_ttl_pkt = icmp_error_generator.generate( icmp.ICMP_TIME_EXCEEDED, icmp.ICMP_TTL_EXPIRED_CODE, msg.data, str(router_port_ip), pkt) unique_key = msg.match.get('reg6') self.dispatch_packet(icmp_ttl_pkt, unique_key) else: LOG.warning("The invalid TTL packet's destination mac %s " "can't be recognized.", e_pkt.dst) def _handle_invalid_dest(self, msg): # If the destination is router interface, the unique key of router # interface will be set to reg7 before sending to local controller. # Code will hit here only when the router interface is not # concrete. if self.port_icmp_unreach_respond_rate_limit(): LOG.warning( "Get more than %(rate)s packets to router port " "per second at table %(table)s", {'rate': self.conf.router_port_unreach_max_rate, 'table': const.L3_LOOKUP_TABLE}) return # Response icmp unreachable to udp or tcp. pkt = packet.Packet(msg.data) tcp_pkt = pkt.get_protocol(tcp.tcp) udp_pkt = pkt.get_protocol(udp.udp) if tcp_pkt or udp_pkt: icmp_dst_unreach = icmp_error_generator.generate( icmp.ICMP_DEST_UNREACH, icmp.ICMP_PORT_UNREACH_CODE, msg.data, pkt=pkt) unique_key = msg.match.get('reg6') self.dispatch_packet(icmp_dst_unreach, unique_key) self._handle_ttl_expired(msg) elif msg.match.get('reg7'): self._handle_invalid_dest(msg) else: return False return True
deleted_lines: self.router_port_rarp_cache = {} self.router_port_rarp_cache.clear() LOG.debug("Get an invalid TTL packet at table %s", const.L3_LOOKUP_TABLE) if self.ttl_invalid_handler_rate_limit(): LOG.warning("Get more than %(rate)s TTL invalid packets per " "second at table %(table)s", {'rate': self.conf.router_ttl_invalid_max_rate, 'table': const.L3_LOOKUP_TABLE}) return True pkt = packet.Packet(msg.data) e_pkt = pkt.get_protocol(ethernet.ethernet) mac = netaddr.EUI(e_pkt.dst) router_port_ip = self.router_port_rarp_cache.get(mac) if router_port_ip: icmp_ttl_pkt = icmp_error_generator.generate( icmp.ICMP_TIME_EXCEEDED, icmp.ICMP_TTL_EXPIRED_CODE, msg.data, str(router_port_ip), pkt) unique_key = msg.match.get('reg6') self.dispatch_packet(icmp_ttl_pkt, unique_key) else: LOG.warning("The invalid TTL packet's destination mac %s " "can't be recognized.", e_pkt.dst) return True if msg.match.get('reg7'): # If the destination is router interface, the unique key of router # interface will be set to reg7 before sending to local controller. # Code will hit here only when the router interface is not # concrete. if self.port_icmp_unreach_respond_rate_limit(): LOG.warning( "Get more than %(rate)s packets to router port " "per second at table %(table)s", {'rate': self.conf.router_port_unreach_max_rate, 'table': const.L3_LOOKUP_TABLE}) return True # Response icmp unreachable to udp or tcp. pkt = packet.Packet(msg.data) tcp_pkt = pkt.get_protocol(tcp.tcp) udp_pkt = pkt.get_protocol(udp.udp) if tcp_pkt or udp_pkt: icmp_dst_unreach = icmp_error_generator.generate( icmp.ICMP_DEST_UNREACH, icmp.ICMP_PORT_UNREACH_CODE, msg.data, pkt=pkt) unique_key = msg.match.get('reg6') self.dispatch_packet(icmp_dst_unreach, unique_key) # Silently drop packet of other protocol. return True # No match in previous code. return False self.router_port_rarp_cache[mac] = dst_ip self.router_port_rarp_cache.pop(mac, None)

commit_message:
Remove CurrentPlanReducer

Current plan state is simple enough that it can become part of plans
state

Change-Id: I135341b41cb4301c5e9ddf7e5f7cc76a99adf577

commit_message:
Plans routing refactor

* Plans are now top level navigation item
* No plan needs to be active by default - fixes the problem when no
  plans exist
* Plan is activated by visiting /plans/<planName> url
* On application initialization (page refresh) currentPlanName in
  in application state is populated from local storage
* Plans selectors have been updated to find plan and plan name based
  on comparing list of a plans to currentPlanName - this ensures that
  active plan always exist
* When a plan is active, user can use breadcrumb navigation to get to
  plan management page and activate/manage plans
* detectPlan action has been removed as it is no longer needed
* Routing has been updated to match new structure

Change-Id: Ia5d4b3444c27edafa5b9209314dead1625dde5ef

commit_message:
bgpvpn_routes_control: API definition fixes

* remove spurious comma in range definition for 'local_pref'
* add validator to allow a field to be an integer in a range or none
  and use it for the local_pref parameter
* the port association 'routes' attribute can be updated

Needed-By: I263e1ee6cf4e1a91be91a4a78f4a160f64d33cc6
Change-Id: I7995209459d5efa020a5e6c6335f4116df7f9f3f

added_lines: LOCAL_PREF_RANGE = [0, 2**32-1] # RFC 4271, section 4.3 (p.18) 'validate': {'type:range_or_none': LOCAL_PREF_RANGE}, ROUTES: {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': True,
deleted_lines: LOCAL_PREF_RANGE = [0, 2**32-1], # RFC 4271, section 4.3 (p.18) 'validate': {'type:range': LOCAL_PREF_RANGE}, ROUTES: {'allow_post': True, 'allow_put': False,

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/09/416409/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =========== network log =========== A **network log** is a container to group security groups or ports for logging. Specified resources can be logged via these event(**all**, **accept** or **drop**). Network v2 network log supported list -------------------------- List all loggable resources .. program:: network log supported list .. code:: bash os network log supported list network log create ------------------ Create a network log for a given project .. program:: network log create .. code:: bash os network log create [--description <description>] [--event <event>] [--resource-type <resource-type>] [--enable-log | --disable-log] [--resource <target> | --no-resource] [--target <target> | --no-target] [--project <project>] [--project-domain <project-domain>] <name> .. _network_log_create-log: .. describe:: <name> Name for the network log. .. option:: --event An event to store with log. .. option:: --resource-type Network log type (default is **security_group**) You can see supported types with following command: openstack network log supported list' .. option:: --enable-log Enable this log (default is disabled). .. option:: --disable-log Disable this log. .. option:: --resource A resource which is enabled to be logged (name or ID). If this option is specified, only this resource\'s event will be collected. .. option:: --no-resource Detach target resource from logging. .. option:: --target Target resource for logging (name or ID). Supported target is **port**. .. option:: --no-target Detach target resource from logging. .. option:: --project <project> Owner's project (name or ID). .. option:: --project-domain <project-domain> Domain the project belongs to (name or ID). This can be used in case collisions between project names exist. .. option:: --description <description> A description of the network log. network log delete ------------------ Delete a given network log .. program:: network log delete .. code:: bash os network log delete <network-log> [<network-log> ...] .. _network_log_delete-log: .. describe:: <network-log> Network log(s) to delete (name or ID) network log list ---------------- List all network logs .. program:: network log list .. code:: bash os network log list [--long] .. option:: --long List additional fields in output network log set --------------- Set network log properties .. program:: network log set .. code:: bash os network log set [--description <description>] [--event <event>] [--resource-type <resource-type>] [--enable-log | --disable-log] [--resource <target> | --no-resource] [--target <target> | --no-target] [--name <name>] <network-log> .. _network_log_set-log: .. describe:: <network-log> Network log set .. option:: --name <name> Set log name .. option:: --description <description> A description of the log. .. option:: --event An event to store with log .. option:: --resource-type Network log type (default is **security_group**) You can see supported types with following command: openstack network log supported list' .. option:: --enable-log Enable this log (default is disabled) .. option:: --disable-log Disable this log .. option:: --resource A resource which is enabled to be logged (name or ID). If this option is specified, only this resource\'s event will be collected. .. option:: --no-resource Detach target resource from logging. .. option:: --target Target resource for logging (name or ID). Supported target is **port** .. option:: --no-target Detach target resource from logging network log show ---------------- Show information of a given network log .. program:: network log show .. code:: bash os network log show <network-log> .. _network_log_show-log: .. describe:: <network-log> Network log to display (name or ID) network log unset ----------------- Unset some attributes from a given network log .. program:: network log unset .. code:: bash os network log unset <network-log> .. _network_log_unset-log: .. describe:: <network-log> Network log to unset (name or ID) .. option:: --enable-log Disable this log .. option:: --resource Detach target resource from logging. .. option:: --target Detach target resource from logging

commit_message:
Add Neutron QoS bandwidth limit rule commands

Create/Update/List/Get/Delete QoS bandwidth limit rules is
now possible to do with shade.

Change-Id: Ife015dd3f9584df901462b3998a4d775374073cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/25/482325/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def search_qos_bandwidth_limit_rules(self, policy_name_or_id, rule_id=None, filters=None): """Search QoS bandwidth limit rules :param string policy_name_or_id: Name or ID of the QoS policy to which rules should be associated. :param string rule_id: ID of searched rule. :param filters: a dict containing additional filters to use. e.g. {'max_kbps': 1000} :returns: a list of ``munch.Munch`` containing the bandwidth limit rule descriptions. :raises: ``OpenStackCloudException`` if something goes wrong during the OpenStack API call. """ rules = self.list_qos_bandwidth_limit_rules(policy_name_or_id, filters) return _utils._filter_list(rules, rule_id, filters) def list_qos_bandwidth_limit_rules(self, policy_name_or_id, filters=None): """List all available QoS bandwith limit rules. :param string policy_name_or_id: Name or ID of the QoS policy from from rules should be listed. :param filters: (optional) dict of filter conditions to push down :returns: A list of ``munch.Munch`` containing rule info. :raises: ``OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound`` if QoS policy will not be found. """ if not self._has_neutron_extension('qos'): raise OpenStackCloudUnavailableExtension( 'QoS extension is not available on target cloud') policy = self.get_qos_policy(policy_name_or_id) if not policy: raise OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound( "QoS policy {name_or_id} not Found.".format( name_or_id=policy_name_or_id)) # Translate None from search interface to empty {} for kwargs below if not filters: filters = {} data = self._network_client.get( "/qos/policies/{policy_id}/bandwidth_limit_rules.json".format( policy_id=policy['id']), params=filters, error_message="Error fetching QoS bandwith limit rules from " "{policy}".format(policy=policy['id'])) return meta.get_and_munchify('bandwidth_limit_rules', data) def get_qos_bandwidth_limit_rule(self, policy_name_or_id, rule_id): """Get a QoS bandwidth limit rule by name or ID. :param string policy_name_or_id: Name or ID of the QoS policy to which rule should be associated. :param rule_id: ID of the rule. :returns: A bandwidth limit rule ``munch.Munch`` or None if no matching rule is found. """ if not self._has_neutron_extension('qos'): raise OpenStackCloudUnavailableExtension( 'QoS extension is not available on target cloud') policy = self.get_qos_policy(policy_name_or_id) if not policy: raise OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound( "QoS policy {name_or_id} not Found.".format( name_or_id=policy_name_or_id)) data = self._network_client.get( "/qos/policies/{policy_id}/bandwidth_limit_rules/{rule_id}.json". format(policy_id=policy['id'], rule_id=rule_id), error_message="Error fetching QoS bandwith limit rule {rule_id} " "from {policy}".format(rule_id=rule_id, policy=policy['id'])) return meta.get_and_munchify('bandwidth_limit_rule', data) def create_qos_bandwidth_limit_rule(self, policy_name_or_id, max_kbps=None, max_burst_kbps=None, direction=None): """Create a QoS bandwidth limit rule. :param string policy_name_or_id: Name or ID of the QoS policy to which rule should be associated. :param int max_kbps: Maximum bandwidth limit value (in kilobits per second). :param int max_burst_kbps: Maximum burst value (in kilobits). :param string direction: Ingress or egress. The direction in which the traffic will be limited. :returns: The QoS bandwidth limit rule. :raises: OpenStackCloudException on operation error. """ if not self._has_neutron_extension('qos'): raise OpenStackCloudUnavailableExtension( 'QoS extension is not available on target cloud') policy = self.get_qos_policy(policy_name_or_id) if not policy: raise OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound( "QoS policy {name_or_id} not Found.".format( name_or_id=policy_name_or_id)) rule = {} if max_kbps: rule['max_kbps'] = max_kbps if max_burst_kbps: rule['max_burst_kbps'] = max_burst_kbps if direction is not None: if self._has_neutron_extension('qos-bw-limit-direction'): rule['direction'] = direction else: self.log.debug( "'qos-bw-limit-direction' extension is not available on " "target cloud") data = self._network_client.post( "/qos/policies/{policy_id}/bandwidth_limit_rules".format( policy_id=policy['id']), json={'bandwidth_limit_rule': rule}) return meta.get_and_munchify('bandwidth_limit_rule', data) def update_qos_bandwidth_limit_rule(self, policy_name_or_id, rule_id, max_kbps=None, max_burst_kbps=None, direction=None): """Update a QoS bandwidth limit rule. :param string policy_name_or_id: Name or ID of the QoS policy to which rule is associated. :param string rule_id: ID of rule to update. :param int max_kbps: Maximum bandwidth limit value (in kilobits per second). :param int max_burst_kbps: Maximum burst value (in kilobits). :param string direction: Ingress or egress. The direction in which the traffic will be limited. :returns: The updated QoS bandwidth limit rule. :raises: OpenStackCloudException on operation error. """ if not self._has_neutron_extension('qos'): raise OpenStackCloudUnavailableExtension( 'QoS extension is not available on target cloud') policy = self.get_qos_policy(policy_name_or_id) if not policy: raise OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound( "QoS policy {name_or_id} not Found.".format( name_or_id=policy_name_or_id)) rule = {} if max_kbps: rule['max_kbps'] = max_kbps if max_burst_kbps: rule['max_burst_kbps'] = max_burst_kbps if direction is not None: if self._has_neutron_extension('qos-bw-limit-direction'): rule['direction'] = direction else: self.log.debug( "'qos-bw-limit-direction' extension is not available on " "target cloud") if not rule: self.log.debug("No QoS bandwidth limit rule data to update") return curr_rule = self.get_qos_bandwidth_limit_rule( policy_name_or_id, rule_id) if not curr_rule: raise OpenStackCloudException( "QoS bandwidth_limit_rule {rule_id} not found in policy " "{policy_id}".format(rule_id=rule_id, policy_id=policy['id'])) data = self._network_client.put( "/qos/policies/{policy_id}/bandwidth_limit_rules/{rule_id}.json". format(policy_id=policy['id'], rule_id=rule_id), json={'bandwidth_limit_rule': rule}) return meta.get_and_munchify('bandwidth_limit_rule', data) def delete_qos_bandwidth_limit_rule(self, policy_name_or_id, rule_id): """Delete a QoS bandwidth limit rule. :param string policy_name_or_id: Name or ID of the QoS policy to which rule is associated. :param string rule_id: ID of rule to update. :raises: OpenStackCloudException on operation error. """ if not self._has_neutron_extension('qos'): raise OpenStackCloudUnavailableExtension( 'QoS extension is not available on target cloud') policy = self.get_qos_policy(policy_name_or_id) if not policy: raise OpenStackCloudResourceNotFound( "QoS policy {name_or_id} not Found.".format( name_or_id=policy_name_or_id)) try: self._network_client.delete( "/qos/policies/{policy}/bandwidth_limit_rules/{rule}.json". format(policy=policy['id'], rule=rule_id)) except OpenStackCloudURINotFound: self.log.debug( "QoS bandwidth limit rule {rule_id} not found in policy " "{policy_id}. Ignoring.".format(rule_id=rule_id, policy_id=policy['id'])) return False return True

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-25 11:49:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent/commit/7e7907197487dff83e2f323abe1bbe4d45189db0', 'message': "Adds Windows support for disk checker

disk_usage on the Floppy Disk Drives and CD / DVD Drives
cannot be retrieved, resulting in errors. Those disk
types has the fs_type = ''. Adds this fs_type to the
fs_types_to_ignore in order to skip them.

The device_name on Windows has the following format: C:\
Trims the device_name to just the drive letter.

The partition mountpoint contains backslashes in Windows,
which are considered invalid characters by the aggregator.
Replaces those characters with forward slashes.

Currently, the disk checker is trying to report the
disk.inode_used_perc. For this, os.statvfs is used,
which coresponds with a Linux specific system call.
This does not exist on Windows.

Skip reporting disk.inode_used_perc metrics on Windows.

Partially-Implements: blueprint add-windows-support

commit_message:
Adds Windows support for disk checker

disk_usage on the Floppy Disk Drives and CD / DVD Drives
cannot be retrieved, resulting in errors. Those disk
types has the fs_type = ''. Adds this fs_type to the
fs_types_to_ignore in order to skip them.

The device_name on Windows has the following format: C:\
Trims the device_name to just the drive letter.

The partition mountpoint contains backslashes in Windows,
which are considered invalid characters by the aggregator.
Replaces those characters with forward slashes.

Currently, the disk checker is trying to report the
disk.inode_used_perc. For this, os.statvfs is used,
which coresponds with a Linux specific system call.
This does not exist on Windows.

Skip reporting disk.inode_used_perc metrics on Windows.

Partially-Implements: blueprint add-windows-support

Change-Id: Ib435a3ac9be12dcfab56fa19a56f761a1a2a275b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/24/320924/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sys # On Windows, the Floppy Disk Drive and the CD / DVD Drive has the # fs_type = ''. Those devices cannot have their disk usage inspected. # We need to ignore those devices, in order to skip errors. fs_types_to_ignore.append('') inode_used_perc = 0 inode_used_perc = self._get_inode_used_perc(partition) # on Windows, the mountpoint contains backslashes, # which are considered invalid characters by the # aggregator. mountpoint = partition.mountpoint.replace('\\', '/') dimensions.update({'mount_point': mountpoint}) if inode_used_perc: inode_used_perc, def _get_inode_used_perc(self, partition): if sys.platform == 'win32': # cannot get value for this. return 0 st = os.statvfs(partition.mountpoint) return round((float(st.f_files - st.f_ffree) / st.f_files) * 100, 2) if sys.platform == 'win32': # on Windows, the device has the following format: C:\ return device[0]
deleted_lines: st = os.statvfs(partition.mountpoint) dimensions.update({'mount_point': partition.mountpoint}) if st.f_files > 0: round((float(st.f_files - st.f_ffree) / st.f_files) * 100, 2),

commit_message:
Adds factory method to AgentChecker

The factory method is needed in order for some
checkers to create proper AgentChecker instances,
depending on some circumstances.

For example, a future patch will add the hypervisor
checker, which will be able to create different types
of AgentCheckers, depending on some configuration
value in its yaml. This is done in order to avoid
duplicating yaml files for each new hypervisor type,
since they need the same configuration options.

Change-Id: I71b14711e680d6eb5a7a3cba630fe6555c8a8ffd
Partially-Implements: blueprint add-windows-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/34/323034/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @classmethod def factory(cls, name, init_config, agent_config, instances=None): """Creates a new check. The purpose of this factory method is to allow checkers to initialize with the proper subclass, if necessary. :param name: The name of the check :param init_config: The config for initializing the check :param agent_config: The global configuration for the agent :param instances: A list of configuration objects for each instance. """ return cls(name, init_config, agent_config, instances)

commit_message:
Adds documentation for monasca-agent on Windows

Adds OpenStackService.exe, which is a Windows service
wrapper, that can be used to create new services,
including for monasca-collector and monasca-forwarder.

Change-Id: I99783a250161fe18da9b252d732f4abc45b2cbd7
Partially-Implements: blueprint add-windows-support
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/66/370066/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: The Agent (monasca-agent) is available for installation from the Python Package Index (PyPI). To install it, you first need `pip` installed on the node to be monitored. Instructions on installing pip may be found at https://pip.pypa.io/en/latest/installing.html. The Agent will NOT run under any flavor of Mac OS at this time but has been tested thoroughly on Ubuntu and should work under most flavors of Linux. Support may be added for Mac OS in the future. Example of an Ubuntu or Debian based install:On Windows, the Agent can be installed using pip. If you do not have pip, you can install it using easy_install: ``` easy_install pip ``` To ensure you are running the latest version of pip: ``` pip install --upgrade pip ``` The Agent can be installed using pip as follows: ``` pip install monasca-agent ``` Next, the Agent must be configured to run as a Windows service. For this, the OpenStackService.exe provided by the monasca-agent is needed. OpenStackService.exe is a Windows service wrapper, that can be used to run any application as a service. It can be downloaded by running the following powershell command: ``` Start-BitsTransfer https://raw.githubusercontent.com/openstack/monasca-agent/master/tools/win32/OpenStackService.exe ``` Alternatively, the monasca-agent project can be cloned locally: ``` git clone https://github.com/openstack/monasca-agent.git ``` Next, OpenStackService.exe will have to be copied somewhere it won't get accidentally deleted: ``` mkdir -Force "C:\Program Files\OpenStack\monasca-agent\" cp OpenStackService.exe "C:\Program Files\OpenStack\monasca-agent\" ``` Finally, the services can be defined as follows: ``` $EtcDir = "C:\Program Files\OpenStack\monasca-agent\etc\" mkdir -Force $EtcDir $OpenStackService = "C:\Program Files\OpenStack\monasca-agent\OpenStackService.exe" # replace this path with the actual Python dir installation. $PythonDir = "path\to\python\dir" $Binary = "`"$OpenStackService`" monasca-collector `"$PythonDir\Scripts\monasca-collector.exe`" --config-file `"$EtcDir\monasca_agent.yaml`" foreground" New-Service -Name monasca-collector -BinaryPathName $Binary -DisplayName "OpenStack Monasca Collector Agent" -StartupType Automatic $Binary = "`"$OpenStackService`" monasca-forwarder `"$PythonDir\Scripts\monasca-forwarder.exe`" --config-file `"$EtcDir\monasca_agent.yaml`"" New-Service -Name monasca-forwarder -BinaryPathName $Binary -DisplayName "OpenStack Monasca Forwarder Agent" -StartupType Automatic ``` The newly created services are going to start automatically on boot. In order to start the services manually, run these powershell commands: ``` Start-Service monasca-collector Start-Service monasca-forwarder ``` To stop them, Stop-Service must be used. To check their status, Get-Service can be used.
deleted_lines: The Agent (monasca-agent) is available for installation from the Python Package Index (PyPI). To install it, you first need `pip` installed on the node to be monitored. Instructions on installing pip may be found at https://pip.pypa.io/en/latest/installing.html. The Agent will NOT run under any flavor of Windows or Mac OS at this time but has been tested thoroughly on Ubuntu and should work under most flavors of Linux. Support may be added for Mac OS and Windows in the future. Example of an Ubuntu or Debian based install:

commit_message:
Adds hypervisor checker factory method

Adds the hypervisor.yaml.example file. It contains the same fields
as the libvirt.yaml file. It also contains the 'hypervisor_type'
field, which will be used by the hypervisor checker's factory
method in order to create proper hypervisor specific checkers.

Adds a map between hypervisor types and their respective checkers.
At the moment, it only contains libvirt.

The hypervisor checker overrides the factory method in order to create the
desired hypervisor specific checker.

Partially-Implements: blueprint add-windows-support

Change-Id: I52627e82ac684fef955286e95e56d595e73f81aa
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/81/353381/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import loggingLOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) @classmethod def factory(cls, name, init_config, agent_config, instances=None): # NOTE(claudiub): this is needed for backwards compatibility. Old # deployments may still have the libvirt.yaml file, meaning that this # checker is loaded and used. # The libvirt.yaml is deprecated, so using it should raise a warning. LOG.warn("The libvirt.yaml file is deprecated, and it shouldn't be " "used to load the Libvirt checker. Please use the " "hypervisor.yaml file instead.") return cls(name, init_config, agent_config, instances)

subject: Hyper-V: replaces in-tree hyper-v utils usage with os_win
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-03 03:19:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent/commit/102145bd9ef0f159040c10bf24e45480470d1675', 'message': 'WIP: Hyper-V: replaces in-tree hyper-v utils usage with os_win

os-win is a library containing Windows / Hyper-V related code.
It contains utils modules that are used by nova, cinder,
networking_hyperv, os-brick. It also contains Hyper-V metrics
related utils, which can be used in ceilometer.

Adds os-win to requirements.txt.
Replaces the current usage of *Utils classes in the
Hyper-V Inspector with the equivalent *Utils classes
from os-win.

Adds decorators to the HyperVInspector methods that prevent
os-win specific exceptions to leak outside the inspector.

Change-Id: I991d141e8983dcd18213f06eb6027de6265871ec

from os-win.

Adds decorators to the HyperVInspector methods that prevent
os-win specific exceptions to leak outside the inspector.

Partially-Implements: blueprint add-windows-support

Change-Id: I991d141e8983dcd18213f06eb6027de6265871ec
'}]
commit_message:
Hyper-V: replaces in-tree hyper-v utils usage with os_win

os-win is a library containing Windows / Hyper-V related code.
It contains utils modules that are used by nova, cinder,
networking_hyperv, os-brick. It also contains Hyper-V metrics
related utils, which can be used in ceilometer.

Adds os-win to requirements.txt.
Replaces the current usage of *Utils classes in the
Hyper-V Inspector with the equivalent *Utils classes
from os-win.

Adds decorators to the HyperVInspector methods that prevent
os-win specific exceptions to leak outside the inspector.

Partially-Implements: blueprint add-windows-support

Change-Id: I991d141e8983dcd18213f06eb6027de6265871ec

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-18 10:31:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent/commit/f02b4026ae70a6b869a138268a3fc750a253546b', 'message': "WIP: Refactors libvirt checker

A lot of the code present in the libvirt checker can be reused
for other future hypervisor checkers (e.g.: _update_instance_cache,
_load_instance_cache, _validate_secgroup, etc.)

Creates the _hypervisor module, which will serve as the base class
for the libvirt and any future hypervisor checker.

The inspector instance has been added as a member of the HypervisorCheck,
so it won't be necessary to pass an inspector to different methods.

Partially-Implements: blueprint add-windows-support

Change-Id: I532ec07cd4a2e69c0d4bff0c27b3ecb0b0a1596b

Adds the hypervisor.yaml.example file. It contains the same fields
as the libvirt.yaml file. It also contains the 'hypervisor_type'
field, which will be used by the hypervisor checker's factory
method in order to create proper hypervisor specific checkers.

Adds a map between hypervisor types and their respective checkers.
At the moment, it only contains libvirt.

The hypervisor checker overrides the factory method in order to create

The argument "hypervisor" has been added to the inspector's

checker to create its own specific Inspector object.
